children.name: sth that you cannot be certain about
uncertain b2
children.definition: uncertain/not certain/ʌnˈsɜːʳtn, nɒt ˈsɜːʳtn/  something that is uncertain, has not been definitely shown or decided:
examples: ▪ the cause of the accident is uncertain.
▪ exactly how and when these plant species came to the great plains is not certain.
it is uncertain whether/if
▪ it is still uncertain whether the conference will actually take place.
it is uncertain how/why/when/that
▪ it’s uncertain when the trial will begin.
▪ it is not at all certain that christopher columbus was the first european to discover america.

children.name: unclear b2
children.definition: unclear/not clear/ʌnˈklɪəʳ, nɒt ˈklɪəʳ/  a situation that is unclear, is one that people do not know enough or understand enough to be sure about it:
examples: ▪ the causes of the dispute are not entirely clear.
▪ at this hour, the fate of the passengers and crew is still unclear.
it is unclear how/why/whether etc
▪ it isn’t clear how the fire started.
▪ it’s not yet clear whether the disease is caused by a virus.
▪ it was unclear when the two sides would meet again to discuss the budget.
it is not clear that
▪ it’s not clear that the problems with the new computer system have been worked out.
unclearadjective không rõ ràng; không minh bạch; khó hiểu
if you are unclear about something, you are not certain about it
_i'm unclear about a couple of points in your proposal - could you go over them again?
_i'm unclear(as to) whether we're meant to stay here or not.

children.name: up in the air x
children.definition: be up in the air/biː ˌʌp ɪn ði ˈeəʳ/  informal use this about something that is uncertain because a decision has not yet been made:
examples: ▪ i might be going on a training course next week, but it’s still up in the air.
▪ they still haven’t said if i’ve got the job -- it’s all up in the air at the moment.

children.name: there is uncertainty c1
children.definition: there is uncertainty about/over something/ðeər ɪz ʌnˈsɜːʳtnti əbaʊt, əʊvəʳ something/ use this to say that people do not feel certain about what has happened or will happen, and are worried about it - used especially in newspapers and public speeches:
examples: ▪ the principal said there was uncertainty about the candidate’s qualifications.
▪ there is some uncertainty over where the refugees are going to be housed.
uncertaintynoun[ c or u ]
when something is not known, or something that is not known or certain
_nothing is ever decided, and all theuncertainty is very bad for staff morale.
_life is full of uncertainties.

children.name: when there are several different opinions about sth
debatable x
children.definition: debatable/dɪˈbeɪtəbəl/  it is debatable whether
examples: ▪ it is debatable whether these alternative medical treatments actually work.
a debatable point
▪ whether or not the government was right to arrest the protesters is an extremely debatable point.

children.name: questionable c2
children.definition: questionable/ˈkwestʃənəbəl/  something that is questionable seems doubtful and is likely to be wrong or untrue:
examples: ▪ the conclusions of the survey are questionable because the research was based on a very small sample of people.
it is questionable whether
▪ it is questionable whether the advertisements will increase sales.

children.name: open to question b2
children.definition: open to question/debate/ˌəʊpən tə ˈkwestʃən, dɪˈbeɪt/  something that is open to question or open to debate seems doubtful and needs to be checked or discussed:
examples: ▪ many people feel that the safety of the drug is now open to question.
▪ just why the guerrillas decided to shoot down the unarmed plane remains open to debate.
it is open to question/debate whether
▪ it is open to debate whether the new government is any better than the old one.

children.name: moot point x
children.definition: moot point/ˌmuːt ˈpɔɪnt/  something that different people have different opinions about: điểm gây tranh cãi
examples: ▪ i’m not sure that bringing in computers has made our job easier. it’s a moot point
▪ whether or not increasing taxes will result in a fairer society remains a moot point.

children.name: when two different results are possible
go either way u
children.definition: sth could go either way informal if you say that something such as a game or a decision could go either way, you mean that either of two results is equally possible:
examples: legal experts following the case believe the trial could go either way.
spurs are a goal up but there are ten minutes to go and the match could still go either way.

children.name: borderline x
children.definition: borderline a borderline case is a situation in which the decision is not certain, for example about whether someone should pass an exam, get a job etc: ranh giới, giới tuyến
examples: borderline case/decision etc
in borderline cases we look at a student’s class work to decide the final exam result.
it was a borderline decision whether to send him to prison or not.

children.name: fifty-fifty chance x
children.definition: there’s a fifty-fifty chance spoken informal if you say there is a fifty-fifty chance of sth happening, you mean there is an equal chance of it happening or not happening:
examples: ▪ the weather forecast said there was a fifty-fifty chance of rain.
be fifty-fiftythere is a fifty-fifty chance
▪ it’ll be a tough game -- i’d say our chances of winning are fifty-fifty.

children.name: toss-up x
children.definition: it’s a toss-up spoken say this when you do not know which of two possibilities someone will choose, and you think each is equally likely:
examples: ‘have you decided where to go on holiday?’ ‘well, it’ll be either portugal or turkey -- it’s a toss-up.’
it’s a toss-up between
i don’t know who’ll get the job. i guess it’s a toss-up between carl and steve.

children.name: when a situation is uncertain, and sth bad may happen
uncertain b2
children.definition: uncertain/ʌnˈsɜːʳtn/
examples: ▪ the situation on the island is still very uncertain and the army is on full alert.
▪ the long-term benefits of the treatment are extremely uncertain.
▪ the economic outlook is so uncertain that i would think carefully before investing any money.
highly uncertainvery uncertain
▪ the company faces a highly uncertain future.

children.name: doubtful b2
children.definition: be/look/remain etc doubtful/biː ˈdaʊtfəl/  to be uncertain and likely to be bad:
examples: ▪ the result of the president’s re-election campaign remains doubtful.
▪ with more and more cuts in government spending, the program’s future now seems doubtful.
it is doubtful if/whether
▪ it is doubtful if she will survive the operation.
▪ it is extremely doubtful whether the aid is actually reaching the people who need it most.
it is doubtful that
▪ it is doubtful that the governor’s proposed tax increase will be popular with voters.

children.name: in doubt b2
children.definition: be in doubt/biː ɪn ˈdaʊt/  if someone or something’s future or success is in doubt, it seems very uncertain and they may not be able to continue or to succeed:
examples: ▪ after yet another injury, his football career is in doubt.
▪ the building’s future remained in doubt until the government agreed to restore it.

children.name: touch and go c2
children.definition: it’s touch and go/ɪts ˌtʌtʃ ən ˈgəʊ/ spoken you say it’s touch and go when a situation seems extremely uncertain and you are worried that something may not happen in the way you want:
examples: ▪ it was touch and go for a few hours, but we were able to get everything out of the basement before it flooded.
▪ an urgent operation was needed to save his life, and doctors said it was touch and go until the end of the procedure.
it’s touch and go whether
▪ traffic was really heavy, and for a while it was touch and go whether they’d get to the wedding on time.

children.name: in the balance c2
children.definition: be/hang in the balance/biː, ˌhæŋ ɪn ðə ˈbæləns/  if something is in the balance or hangs in the balance, there is a risk that something bad will happen so that it will not continue:
examples: ▪ the survival of the african elephant hangs in the balance.
▪ his career as a politician hung in the balance
.▪ i can’t say what the outcome of the talks will be -- they’re very much in the balance at the moment

children.name: iffy x
children.definition: iffy/ˈɪfi/  spoken informal use this to describe a plan or situation that seems uncertain and may not succeed or happen as you want:
examples: ▪ ‘what’s happening about your new job?’ ‘the whole thing’s rather iffy at the moment.’
▪ i was hoping to go to the beach today but it’s looking iffy because of the weather.

children.name: not sure if sth is true or if sth will happen
not certain b1
children.definition: not certain/nɒt ˈsɜːʳtn/  not sure about something. not certain is more formal than not sure:không chắc
examples: ▪ the man you’re looking for could be keith, but i’m not certain.
not certain about: không chắc về điều gì
▪ i’m not certain about what time the buses come - i usually cycle.
not certain how/why/where etc: không chắc như thế nào/tại sao/ở đâu
▪ i’m really not certain how much fuel we’ve got left.

children.name: not know a2
children.definition: not know/nɒt ˈnəʊ/  to not be at all sure if something is true or if something will happen:không biết/không chắc
examples: ▪ ‘how old is she?’ ‘oh, i don’t know - fifty, fifty-five?’
not know if/whether/how etc: không chắc nếu/liệu/như thế nào
▪ i phoned her but i don’t know if she got my message.
▪ we do not know whether the lake is safe for swimming in.
not know for sureespeciallyspoken:không biết chắc
▪ it could be this week but it might be much later. we don’t know for sure.

children.name: unsure b2
children.definition: unsure/uncertainb2  unsure and uncertain are more formal than not sure and not certain.:không chắc
examples: unsure/uncertain about:không chắc về
▪ i’m still a bit unsure about how to use this software.
unsure/uncertain of: không chắc về cái gì
▪ many workers are still unsure of their rights.
unsure/uncertain who/what/whether etc:không chắc ai/cái gì/liệu
▪ david decided to become a teacher but was uncertain which subject to specialize in.

children.name: doubt b1
children.definition: doubt/daʊt/  a feeling of not being sure whether something is true or correct: nghi ngờ
examples: doubt about
▪ there are still some doubts about her suitability for the job.
doubt as to
▪ there seems to be some doubt as to what warnings were given.

children.name: wonder b1
children.definition: wonder/ˈwʌndəʳ/  to think about something that you are not sure about, and try to guess what is true, what will happen, etc:tự hỏi
examples: ▪ he says he’s had no formal training but when you see how good his work is, you start to wonder.
wonder if/how/whether etc: tự hỏi nếu/liệu/...
▪ i wonder if she’ll recognize me after all these years.
▪ he wondered whether he would be able to find the hotel again.

children.name: not sure a2
children.definition: not sure/nɒt ˈʃʊəʳ/ không chắc
examples: ▪ ‘what time does the film start?’ ‘i think it’s 8.30, but i’m not sure.’
not sure how/whether/when etc: không chắc như thế nào/liệu/khi nào/...
▪ i’m not sure where she lives.
▪ i’m not sure how long it will take the bus to get there.
not sure about: không chắc về
▪ if you’re not sure about the meaning of a word, look it up in a dictionary
not sure of: không chắc về cái gì
▪ use the ‘filesearch’ function if you are not sure of the name of a file.
can’t be surespoken when you think something is true, but you are not completely sure
▪ i can’t be sure, but i think i saw maggie coming out of the hospital this morning.

children.name: question b2
children.definition: questionnounproblem
examples: [ u ] doubt or confusion
_there's no questionabout(= it is certain) whose fault it is.
_whether children are reading fewer books isopen toquestion (= there is some doubt about it).
_her loyalty isbeyondquestion (= there is no doubt about it) .
_there's no question that he's guilty.

children.name: not quite b2
children.definition: not quite
examples: used to express that you are not certain about something
_i don't quite know what to say.
_i didn't quite catch what he said.

children.name: uncertainty c2
children.definition: uncertainty
examples: 1[ uncountable ] when you feel doubt about what will happen :
times of great change are also times of uncertainty.
uncertainty about/as to
there is a great deal ofuncertaintyaboutthecompany’sfuture.
2[ countable usually plural ] a situation which you are not sure about because you do not know what will happen :
life’s uncertainties
uncertainty of
the uncertainties of old age

children.name: or other c1
children.definition: or otherinformal
examples: used when you cannot or do not want to be exact about the information you are giving
_the event was held insomepark or other.
_we'll findsomeoneor other to help us.

children.name: indefinitely
children.definition: adverb
examples: for a period of time with no fixed end
_the negotiations have beenput off/postponedindefinitely.

children.name: questionable c2
children.definition: questionableadjective
examples: not certain, or wrong in some way
_itis questionablewhether this goal can be achieved.
_much of late-night television is of questionablevalue/taste.
